Let's call this the game state for now: One of the most consequential shifts in American foreign policy may occur sometime before the 2020 election. Conditions are ripe for a Republican president to strike a deal that could substantially reduce but not eliminate the North Korean nuclear threat. Republican acceptance of such a deal, even as an “initial” agreement with the promise of more to come, would undo a few decades of bipartisan orthodoxy requiring the irreversible denuclearization of North Korea. I took a "frequentist" approach: in about 70 years there has been no visit from a NK leader to Seoul, there are three months till 01/10/2019, a baseline probability is about (1 / 4) * (1 / 70), about 0.3%, which I multiply by about 3 to take into account the ongoing peace process.

In 2018 alone, the stalemate between both Korean states have begun to thaw as their respective leaders, North Korean Supreme Leader Kim Jong Un and South Korean President Moon Jae-In made history by holding the first summit at the Peace House within the Demilitarized Zone. This summit is known for being symbolic for 1) stating a commitment to denuclearization, and 2) having the Panmunjon Declaration. Since then, 2 other summits have been held between North Korea and South Korea, but the long-awaited visit to Seoul has yet to come to fruition since 2018. It will be a historical moment when the Seoul Summit is held, which must be held for both symbolic and political significance. Plenty of preparatory work must be done between these states, as well as an intention for the Summit to occur. While the possibility of Kim visiting Seoul exists, but there does not seem to be a concerted effort to iron out details of a summit within the next 3 months in general. A few key developments which support the likelihood of Kim's visit to Seoul: the aforementioned 2 inter-state summits between North Korea and South Korea that happened within 6 months of the maiden Peace House Summit all within 2018; most recently Kim's sister -representing the delegate of North Korea- visiting the DMZ to commemorate the death of the former South Korean first lady. These are all symbolic gestures, with the third summit occurring in North Korea's capital, Pyongyang, speaking volumes on a commitment to potentially ending the armistice and declaring the inter-state Korean war to be symbolically over, and potential reunification. These developments give a decent possibility that Kim may visit Seoul eventually. However, thinking that the visit to Seoul occurring before 1st October 2019 seems like a quantum leap to make. Firstly, there has not been a commitment from both countries to work towards the Seoul summit, and given the short timeframe available, it seems highly unlikely. Even if there would be more time available for both countries to work out a schedule, the agenda for the meeting, presumably on honoring the Panmujom Declaration and work towards denuclearization, must happen at the opportune moment. South Korea has been the mediator for the latter commitment towards denuclearization, but seeing how North Korea and the US are still at loggerheads on an agreement between disarmament and lifting embargoes, this author doubts that even South Korea's mediation now would provide an effective solution. Currently, both countries are embroiled in their own political affairs to commit to the Seoul Summit. Kim's international visits now are geared towards securing an ally in China, a potential economic partner and ally who provides a counterweight against the US. And while Moon is expecting a visit from Trump to again be the mediator for talks of nuclear disarmament, he has not augur or make explicit the commitment to a Seoul Summit. They could just as easily meet at another city, or at the Peace House again.

Update:

The latest events have an influence on the South-North Korean relations, as well as on the US-North Korean relations. Kim Jong Un’s sister, Kim Yo Jong, met South Korean officials in the demilitarised zone last Wednesday. She expressed her condolences on behalf of North Korea concerning the death of former first lady Lee Hee-Ho. Lee and her husband, former president Kim Dae-Jung, are known for their commitment for a peaceful reunification of both Koreas. Therefore, the act of paying respect should be seen as a symbolic gesture of North Korea to South Korea. Indeed, this represents another step for improved relations between both Koreas. Furthermore, North Korea sent a positive formulated letter to Trump, according to the US president. Trump will be visiting South Korea at the end of June before he departures to the G20 summit in Japan. Indeed, this could be a possibility that Kim Jong Un and Trump will meet in Seoul in order to revive their negotiations as both parties declared their interest to continue these.
Less time, no signs of it happening

Update: as a sign of warming relations could be taken that Kim Jong Un’s sisters went to the country’s militarized southern border to deliver a condolence message over the death of a former South Korean first lady who promoted unity between the rivals whilst being the first lady to the stateman promoting the Sunshine Policy. This could be seen as a sign of warming relations. Yet, it is still unlikely that a visit will take place before the time frame of October 2019. https://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2019/06/12/asia-pacific/politics-diplomacy-asia-pacific/kim-jong-uns-sister-visit-dmz-honor-late-former-south-korean-first-lady-seoul-says/#.XQOWu9MzYb0
Down from 35% due to passage of time.

Update: Kim Jong-un's sister, Kim Yo-jong, recently met with a South Korean delegation at the border to pass on condolences in the wake of the passing of the former first lady of South Korea. However, reports indicate that the meeting solely concerned the exchange of the letter of condolence, and no further political discussions were had. While a North Korean delegation might attend the funeral of the former first lady, it remains extremely unlikely that Kim Jong-un should participate and a near visit to Seoul seems unlikely. Hence, despite this recent high-level contact, the current disputes over the future of Korean economic collaborations weights more heavily and I decrease my prediction to 5%.

Negotiations are still stalled and there seems to be no signs of Pompeo or Bolton leaving. Despite calls from North Korea to lift sanctions, they still remain in in place and Bolton claims that the US is open to a third summit, but that the ball is in Kim Jong Un's court. As I've previously stated a visit to Seoul would only happen after a successful third summit, but it doesn't look like that summit will happen any time soon as neither party is budging.

The Russia/China/North Korea bloc will become stronger and resources to keep Kim Jong Un propped up will keep coming in form the East while they build a very robust cyber warfare and surveillance network among the 3 countries.

Not looking good for Bolton: President Donald Trump said Tuesday that North Korean leader Kim Jong Un has "kept his word" when it comes to nuclear and missile testing, contradicting his own national security adviser, John Bolton, who just hours earlier had accused Pyongyang of failing to follow through on its commitments.

While there at the beginning of this year were many positive signs pointing at further collaboration and negotiations between the leaders of North Korea and South Korea (https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-46714299, https://worldin2019.economist.com/northkoreaandunitedstates). Including the announcement following the September 2018 inter-Korean summit, were it was announced by Kim & Moon that Kim would visit Seoul by the end of the year (2018) (https://uk.reuters.com/article/uk-northkorea-southkorea-summit/north-koreas-kim-says-to-scrap-missile-sites-visit-seoul-idUKKCN1LY30K). However, the visit did not happen, and as of today (9/6-19), a visit had not been announced.

Update I don't see any recent big effort in order to reconnect to SK, instead, Kim Jong Un seems to try to ingratiate Russia to further close cooperation. The NK leader has recently met Putin, trying to find an alternative ally after having stated aggressive comments against Trump and the not satisfactory Hanoi meeting. As I said in my first forecast, I think that NK will want to get out of the marginalization process in which it is from decades, but it's not ready yet for a reconnection with Seoul neither with the Western countries, preferring old ally as Russia. Indeed, Russia seats at the table of UN security council as permanent member, and for Kim Jong Un could represent a chance to have a voice in the Council and (maybe) reduce the international community sanctions applied to NK. Moreover, after the international conviction to Russia for its intervention in Crimea, Putin might re-acquire some prestige in taking the role of peacemaker, re-connecting with NK and introducing NK issues to the UNSC. For these reasons, I reduce my forecast to 10%

I.e. He might meet with Moon but not in Seoul, as this would indicate a familiarity or sign of compliance with South Korea that Jong Un does not wish to further. However, considering the limited information, the unpredictable nature of Kim Jong Un (and my lack of understanding of the situation), I stick with my 7% probability.

Typically to answer a question on GJO, a good starting point is a baseline. How often does something similar happens? In order to answer this question, some of my fellow forecasters looked at the meetings of the East/West German leaders. Some others at the visits of american presidents to Vietnam/Cuba. I do believe, that asserting baseline is very important, but in case of South/North Korea it is impossible to compare to other cases. The dynamics of the relationship, and Kim Jong Uns (one man) world perception of is crucial, which disables all comparison to other cases. That is why, I will jump right away into looking at the inner relationship between South/North Korea and if they are motivated to meet.

Closing window of opportunity: Approximately 80 days elapsed between Kim Yo Jong's invitation and the groundbreaking April 27th summit. The Seoul summit would demand the same level of planning if not more. That leaves about 50 days (mid-July latest) for inter-Korean relations to reverse course in such a way that summits are back on the table. Treating this as a Poisson distribution with lambda=.47 (# of summits since Jan 1, 2018/days since Jan 1, 2018*days left) gives a 29% chance of a summit occurring. I'm going to push this number down due to 22% due to the current climate (decreasing lambda by 40%).

For the people who don’t want to read everything: My estimated base rate suggests that a visit has almost always happened after 66 years in comparable cases. I therefore think that many other forecasters are way overconfident when they estimate probabilities in the 0-5% range. @pietrokc reached a similar conclusion. I recognise that the short term relationship between the leaders plays an important part nonetheless. The inside view points our attention to some serious obstacles in the short term, most importantly the timeframe of the question, which lowers my estimate. Also the symbolic significance and security concerns of a North Korean visit to Seoul, recent missile test by NK and somewhat of a standstill in the U.S-NK nuclear disarmament negotiations. These obstacles lower my estimate significantly, but no further than to 30%.

Other forecaster pointed into the right direction how to engage with this question. The analogy between South-North Korea and West-East Germany is more than obvious (@mbayer123 offers good arguments for the comparability of both situations). This forecast will identify key events and underlying socio-political drivers which influenced the reunification in Germany and analyse if similar (or contradicting) key events and drivers can be found in the Korean reconciliation process. Comparing the current events on the Korean peninsula with the historic development in Germany should improve the accuracy of this forecast as it offers a structured orientation to analyse the events taking place.

Update During the past week, NK has tested some new military tools launching long-range multiple rocket launchers, short-range missiles and tactical guided missiles. , Kim Jong Un has also reiterated his conviction that security is guaranteeed only by the presence of a strong and well-equipped State. Even if this event is not completely surprising for the US neither South Korea (this is something going on since long time, and some summits are not enough to guarantee the complete engagement of NK in a peaceful collaboration), surely it is a step back in the de-nuclearization purpose, so much hoped by SK but very unlikely to happen in the short-term. Because of this information and my previous forecast assumptions, I see as even less likely a visit in Seoul by NK president before 1 October (4 months and a half), I decrease the percentage of my forecast. However, these provocations could also have the contrary effect of leading to have more talks between SK-US-NK, maybe even using the removal of sanctions as bargaining chip. https://www.ilfattoquotidiano.it/2019/04/24/russia-kim-jong-un-in-visita-ufficiale-e-la-prima-volta-da-quando-mosca-si-e-avvicinata-alla-sud-corea-capitalista/5133045/

The visit of Kim Jong Un to Seoul will be of significant importance for the contemporary international relations. However, I don’t see it happening before 1 October 2019 and, therefore, I give it 5% chance.
Has no reason to visit S. Korea.

First of all, this would be an unprecedented event. The best comparison would be Erich Honecker being the first East German leader to visit West Germany in 1987. As history shows this happened during a time of increasing relations and the slow loosening of soviet restrictions, resulting in the fall of the Berlin wall just two years after Honecker's visit. This would suggest that a Kim Jong Un visit to Seoul would be done during times of change and improving relations. This of course isn't a great comparison, but it does show how rare these types of events are.

President Trump has met twice with North Korean leader Kim Jong Un to discuss the issue of denuclearizing the Korean Peninsula. Recent provocative NK missile tests are likely less an imminent threat to any nation than a "poke" to states in the region to remind them of NK capability. Both Kim Jong Un and President Trump are high visibility personalities with a penchant for winning. President Moon Jae-in of South Korea can use (and arguably needs) such a meeting to occur- successful or otherwise- to boost his approval rating. Kim Jong Un will likely visit Seoul before 01 October 2019, and take the meeting to show he can disagree and say no in a way that augments goodwill. NK's weapons programs will continue in the near-term to promote its perceived balance of power; while involved leadership will enjoy the spotlight displaying their negotiation acumen. President Trump and President Moon Jae have the most to lose of the three in terms of international confidence- and reelection hopes- if the meeting does not happen.
Not before US sanctions are lifted
Regardless, it will most likely happen within the next year

President Moon of South Korea was hopeful that the second U.S.-North Korea Summit would end with a deal that could bring peace to the peninsula and economic prosperity to his country. He met Mr. Kim twice on the inter-Korean border to diffuse the conflict between the US and North Korea, and to help in this meeting between the two countries. However, the second summit did not end with a deal and ruined plans of Mr. Kim visiting South Korea in the near future. A visit to South Korea by Mr. Kim would be significant as he would be the first North Korean leader to ever visit, and this would be a integral step to improving economic relations between the two countries. Although the meeting was not successful and it is very unlikely that Mr. Kim will visit South Korea's capital before October, Mr. Moon remains hopeful that a resolution will occur because both sides parted on good terms.
Forecast-Update #2:

Kim Jong Un is not fully satisfied about the last meeting between him and Trump, where the deal seemed to conclude in a brief summary two things: for North Korea to dismantle all its nuclear weapons so that following affirmative removal of the missiles that makes NK fairly unstable partner, the US is willing to lift some of the sanctions currently put on North Korea. However, the summit in Vietnam did not end in a signed deal between the US and North Korea mainly due to the request from North Korean side that the exchange for the nuclear program removal should be lifting of all sanctions, not just some. The risk that prevents the US from accepting such step is the risk of North Korea simply freezing the missile program which in itself contains multiple regional and global security risks. And this risk has somehow realized yesterday with news breaking that Kim Jong Un was supervising the first missile test since 2017. It was a solid fuel SRBM with multiple projectiles directed towards Japan signaling the end of the NK's nuclear coma. The response from US was sensitive with Trump insisting in a tweet that a deal between the US and North Korea is possible. A very diplomatic move but also quite mild having in mind the historic account of responses Trump usually takes when it comes to other rogue states or states that do not comply with the American set rules. Therefore, it could be seen that the US is willing to set a deal, however South Korea is concerned according to official statements due to the difference between nuclear freeze and nuclear program dismantle. Therefore, having in mind the now unstable and still evolving activities between the US, North Korea and South Korea, it seems that it is not impossible, but the chances are relatively low in the temporal framework set up by the question. The prospects for Kim Jong Un visiting Seoul after October 2019 are much more optimistic.

Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe and U.S. President Donald Trump are set to talk by telephone on Monday and discuss projectiles fired by North Korea, national broadcaster NHK said. From: https://www.reuters.com/article/us-northkorea-missiles-japan/japans-abe-and-trump-to-discuss-north-korea-on-monday-nhk-idUSKCN1SC0OU

The leader of North Korea has an incentive to visit South Korea, so he can improve relations. However, this is dependent on if he wants to improve relations. If Kim Jong-Un does not, then there is not point in visiting. At this point in time, I believe that there is an equal chance that Kim Jong-Un will visit or not visit Seoul because his interests are unknown.

I think that if something very tragic happened to their already fragile economy, Kim Jong Un would consider visiting Seoul before 1 October 2019. However, October is only a little over 5 months away, meaning something really pressing would have to happen for him to decide this quickly to meet. Reports do add that it would be enticing for him to go, seeing as he would be the first North Korean leader to visit the South. Additionally, talks with South Korea could also result in more economic stimulation for North Korea. Nonetheless, my very slim probability is due to his recent missile testing activity as of the beginning of May, 2019. Sure, these tests were reported as being short range tests and North Korea is really only restricted by creating long range missiles. But a BBC report noted that North Korea is still working with radioactive material. Base line or rather point of departure for the forecast at hand are the summit meetings between the heads of the Federal Republic of Germany (BRD) and the German Democratic Republic (GDR), respectively. This comparison is made due to several similarities. First, in both cases former united nations were separated after World War II. Consequently, as a second similarity, both cases share a certain form of system competition with both the BRD and South Korea having won this competition. While North Korea is struggling, both in terms of economical parameters, as well as international standing, South Korea has developed into a stable, mature democracy. As a modern industrial country, it belongs to the countries with higher incomes and is a member of the OECD and G20, among others (https://www.swp-berlin.org/fileadmin/contents/products/research_papers/2018RP12_hlp_mro_eds.pdf#page=12). Thus, it does not come as a surprise that both cases also share the same refugee movement from east to west and north to south, respectively (https://www.deutschlandfunk.de/nord-und-suedkorea-die-euphorie-ist-der-realitaet-gewichen.724.de.html?dram:article_id=447159). Another crucial similarity touches upon the reconciliation processes or rather attempts. Even though both BRD and South Korean societies were/are majority-wise in favor of the reconciliation, they were/are still divided. Nevertheless, both the BRD and South Korea kept pushing the reconciliation process. Thereby, both reconciliation processes experienced ups and downs ((https://www.swp-berlin.org/fileadmin/contents/products/research_papers/2018RP12_hlp_mro_eds.pdf#page=12).

Confirmation bias? Japan drops ‘maximum pressure’ on North Korea from foreign policy playbook, wants to normalise ties with Kim regime ... In last year’s “Diplomatic Bluebook”, published when tensions on the Korean peninsula were soaring, Japan said it was coordinating efforts with its allies to “maximise pressure on North Korea by all available means.” But this language was dropped from this year’s edition, drawn up after diplomats had “taken comprehensively into account the latest developments surrounding North Korea”, according to chief government spokesman Yoshihide Suga. “There have been major developments in the situation surrounding North Korea in light of events such as the US-North Korea summits in June last year and February,” Suga told reporters.

North Korean leadership has bobbed back and forth between an aggressive stance towards the US and South Korea and adopting a softer tone. By recording the "positive" moves, of which this would be a huge one, their actions can be gauged. Over the past ten years, these events have occurred on these dates: August 2009, October 2014, January 2018, April 2018, and June 2018 (from https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-pacific-15278612). North Korea seems to have cycles, where easing of tensions occurs roughly every four years. After a lackluster February 2019 summit between the US and North Korea, it seems like the softer stance period may be over (from http://time.com/5565816/south-north-korea-trump-kim-moon-sanctions/). There would need to be a rapid improvement in relations in order to have Kim Jong Un visit Seoul, and while its possible that some improvements between the US/South Korea and North Korea may occur, there is just so much that would need to change in order for an event of such magnitude to happen. Best to err on the side of what has happened in the past and recognize that this just isn't feasible at the present time.

He also defined himself regret not having done that before. - Last year in this period (On April 27), Kim Jong-Un crossed the military line that divides the two Koreas, becoming the first North Korean leader since the end of the Korean War to do so. In 2018, Kim Jong Un has met with Moon Jae-in. The visits occurred twice in a border village, and once in Pyongyang. Kim Jong Un has not actually visited in South Korea as of now. In 2018 he promised a visit to Seoul, but he failed to follow through. However, 2018 also saw Jung Un re-state his intentions of close collaborations between the North and South Korea in a letter to President Moon Jae-in (https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/dec/30/kim-jong-un-vows-to-meet-south-koreas-leader-frequently-in-2019=)

In a letter sent by Kim Jong Un to Seoul, North Korean (NK) leader expressed regret for having not visited the capital in 2018 and vowed to meet frequently with President Moon Jae-in in 2019 to pursue NK-SK peace and ‘solve the issue of denuclearisation together.’ Moon has welcomed Kim’s intention to seek agreements. Moon has also been a supporter of US and NK negotiations, and saw the breakdown of US-NK summit in Vietnam as a setback. He has since called for a semi-official talks between the three countries — US, NK and SK — to keep the dialogue going. An unprecedented willingness on both sides to negotiate agreements points to the real plausibility of an official meeting this year. To date however, the NK-SK meetings have occurred at the peninsula or in Pyongyang.

First, it is to be underlined that there's actually the political will on both sides to have a meeting in Seoul. As BBC news notes, "North Korea's leader Kim Jong-un has vowed to "frequently" meet South Korea's President Moon Jae-in next year to discuss denuclearisation. In a rare letter to Seoul, Mr Kim said he wished to pursue peace between the countries and "solve the issue of denuclearising the peninsula together", a spokesman for Mr Moon said. Mr Kim also expressed "much regret" that he could not visit Seoul in 2018 (https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-46714299). This is itself historical, as Kim would be the first North Korean leader visiting Seoul (https://www.nytimes.com/2018/12/10/world/asia/kim-jong-un-visit-seoul.html). Kim and Moon already met three times, and there's the will to meet again in Seoul. That said, it is definetly difficult to assess if it's going to happen before the 1st of October. These kinds of historical events could take place in any day or during symbolic and important recurrencies: june 6 is the memorial day (honoring soldiers and civilians who died for their country), august 15 celebrates the liberation from Japan's occupation, etc (https://english.visitkorea.or.kr/enu/TRV/TV_ENG_1_1.jsp). That said, South Korea is a historical US ally, and it's definetly foreseeable that North-South Korean relations will be influenced by US-North Korea talks about nuclear disarmament (for a way too detailed chronology, see https://www.armscontrol.org/factsheets/dprkchron whose sum up is that relations are going pretty well, eventhough there's still not a deal about disarmament for releif from economic sanctions). The US-North Korea talks will probably take a while, the issue discussed are very delicate and strictly linked to sovereignty. Taken into account all these factors, I would say that the visit to Seoul is more likely to happen after the first of October, but I don't exclude it either.

Preceding inter-Korean summits include 2000 (2.5 years into KDJ’s presidency) and 2007 (4.8 years into RMH’s presidency), and 2018 (1 year into MJI’s presidency). NK and the USA shifted from “fire and fury” to detente in less than a year. 2 months elapsed between NK’s proposal for talks and the April 2018 summit. This illustrates that we shouldn't be too hung up on what's happening in the news of the day. Things can change in a matter of weeks or months in either direction.

Through inter-Korean history, meetings between the two heads of state have been held several times in North Korea (visit of South Korean Kim Dae-Jung in 2000 to Pyongyang, South Korean President Roh Moo-hyun in 2007 in the same city, and recently Moon Jae-in in April and September 2018), but never in Seoul, South Korea. 2018 is a year marked by a strong rapprochement in the Peninsula. Indeed, after nuclear tests in the North, Seoul proposed a meeting on January 9, 2018, which resulted in a North Korean delegation to the Winter Olympic Games in PyeongChang, South Korea, as well as the visit of the North Korean leader's sister, Kim Yo-Jong, first member of the North Dynasty to visit South Korea since 1953.

I find it highly unlikely that Kim Jong Un would meet in Seoul, given the failure of the summit in Hanoi in February and that no prior meetings have ever taken place in Seoul. To meet in Seoul before successfully entering agreements with other countries could be interpreted as a sign of weakness by the SK’s. It would show that Kim is so desperate for allies he is willing to go into what is for all intents and purposes enemy territory (as the Korean war has not officially ended). While it could be interpreted as a sign of goodwill, for a man whose regime is built on a godlike persona, this move would not look good domestically and would weaken the threat of a viable nuclear program, which could impede NK’s international and domestic goals. Unless some major event occurs between the two countries between now and October, I think it is unlikely such a meeting would take place. It may happen later in the future, but given the current state of affairs, it does not seem to benefit Kim enough to take such a step. https://www.cnbc.com/2019/02/28/white-house-trump-kim-meetings-change-of-schedule.html https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/white-house/u-s-drops-demand-full-accounting-n-korea-nuclear-program-n977251
